title: Resources & Further Reading
text:
Why ‚ÄúPartnership‚Äù Language?
Industry professionals typically say they ‚Äúuse AI tools.‚Äù We deliberately chose different language‚Äîand understanding why matters for teaching.

The Problem with ‚ÄúTool Use‚Äù Framing
When we say ‚ÄúI use a tool,‚Äù we imply:

The human is fully in control
The tool is passive until activated
Agency flows one direction: human ‚Üí tool
The human remains unchanged by the interaction

But this isn‚Äôt what actually happens in cybersecurity operations.


What‚Äôs Really Happening in a SOC
Consider a Security Operations Center analyst working with a SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) system:

The SIEM shapes perception ‚Äî Before the analyst sees anything, the system has already decided what counts as ‚Äúsuspicious.‚Äù Thousands of events are filtered, correlated, and prioritized. The analyst‚Äôs awareness is bounded by what the tool surfaces.
The analyst adapts to the tool ‚Äî Experienced analysts learn to ‚Äúthink like the SIEM‚Äù‚Äîunderstanding its detection logic, anticipating its blind spots, structuring their investigations around its capabilities.
Agency is distributed ‚Äî When a threat is detected, who found it? The analyst who investigated? The SIEM that flagged it? The rule-writer who configured the detection? The answer is: the assemblage of all of them together.
Neither succeeds alone ‚Äî The SIEM can‚Äôt understand context, institutional knowledge, or human factors. The analyst can‚Äôt process millions of log entries. Together, they accomplish what neither could individually.



Why This Matters for Education
Teaching students that they ‚Äúuse AI tools‚Äù sets up a false mental model that will fail them in professional practice. They‚Äôll either:

Over-rely on AI (assuming it ‚Äúhandles‚Äù security while they ‚Äúuse‚Äù it)
Under-utilize AI (treating it as a simple lookup tool rather than an investigative partner)
Miss the mutual shaping (not recognizing how AI recommendations influence their perception)

The ‚Äúpartnership‚Äù framing we use throughout these activities isn‚Äôt merely aspirational‚Äîit‚Äôs preparation for the actual cognitive work of modern cybersecurity operations.


Theoretical Foundation
This approach draws from posthuman educational theory, particularly:

Rosi Braidotti‚Äôs work on human-technology entanglement and distributed agency
Catherine Adams and Terrie Lynn Thompson‚Äôs practical heuristics for examining how digital technologies shape human perception and practice‚Äîwhat they call ‚Äúinterviewing‚Äù digital objects to understand their contributions to our work

These theoretical insights translate directly into developing cybersecurity expertise. When students learn to see AI as a partner with distinct capabilities, limitations, and influence on their own thinking, they‚Äôre developing the meta-cognitive awareness that distinguishes expert practitioners.






NoteFor Further Reading



The references in the Human-AI Collaboration & Posthuman Pedagogy section below provide deeper theoretical grounding for this approach.

title: Resources & Further Reading
text:
Human-AI Collaboration & Posthuman Pedagogy
These works provide theoretical and practical foundations for understanding humans and AI as collaborative partners rather than tool-user relationships.

Researching a Posthuman World: Interviews with Digital Objects
Adams, C., & Thompson, T. L. (2016). Researching a Posthuman World: Interviews with Digital Objects. Palgrave Pivot.
Empirical

Why This Matters: Introduces eight practical heuristics for investigating human-technology relationships in educational settings. The ‚Äúinterviewing objects‚Äù approach directly informs how we frame AI as a team member with its own capabilities and limitations‚Äîexactly the perspective these activities develop in students.

Publisher Link


The Posthuman
Braidotti, R. (2013). The Posthuman. Polity Press.
Theoretical

Why This Matters: Foundational text redefining what it means to be human in an age of technological entanglement. Braidotti‚Äôs framework helps educators move beyond anthropocentric assumptions‚Äîessential for teaching students that effective cybersecurity emerges from human-AI assemblages, not human dominance over tools.

Publisher Link


Artificial Intelligence in Education: Promises and Implications for Teaching and Learning
Holmes, W., Bialik, M., & Fadel, C. (2019). Artificial Intelligence in Education: Promises and Implications for Teaching and Learning. Center for Curriculum Redesign.
Framework

Why This Matters: Comprehensive examination of AI‚Äôs role in education with practical implications for classroom implementation. Addresses both opportunities and challenges educators face when integrating AI, including equity considerations relevant to the low-resource implementation options in these activities.

Publisher Link


Designing Educational Technologies in the Age of AI
Luckin, R., & Cukurova, M. (2019). Designing educational technologies in the age of AI: A learning sciences-driven approach. British Journal of Educational Technology, 50(6), 2824-2838.
Empirical

Why This Matters: Establishes design principles for educational AI that positions technology as a collaborative partner. Their framework for ‚Äúintelligence augmentation‚Äù aligns directly with the partnership model in these activities, where AI contributes pattern recognition while humans provide contextual judgment.

DOI: 10.1111/bjet.12861


Posthumanism and Educational Research
Snaza, N., & Weaver, J. A. (Eds.). (2014). Posthumanism and Educational Research. Routledge.
Theoretical

Why This Matters: Collection exploring how posthumanist theory transforms educational practice. Multiple chapters address technology-mediated learning and challenge traditional human-centered pedagogies‚Äîproviding theoretical grounding for why ‚ÄúAI as teammate‚Äù represents a more accurate and productive framing than ‚ÄúAI as tool.‚Äù

Publisher Link

title: Resources & Further Reading
text:
Cybersecurity Education Research
Research and frameworks specifically addressing cybersecurity education, including K-12 approaches, hands-on learning, and workforce development.

K-12 Cybersecurity Learning Standards
CYBER.org. (2021). K-12 Cybersecurity Learning Standards (Version 1.0).
Official

Why This Matters: The definitive K-12 standards document that these activities align with. Provides grade-band progressions and learning objectives that educators can use to connect activities to curriculum requirements. Essential reference for understanding scope and sequence in cybersecurity education.

CYBER.org Standards


Cybersecurity Education in K-12: An Exploratory Study
Catota, F. E., Morgan, M. G., & Sicker, D. C. (2019). Cybersecurity education in a developing nation: The Ecuadorian environment. Journal of Cybersecurity, 5(1), tyz001.
Empirical

Why This Matters: Though focused on Ecuador, this study provides transferable insights into adapting cybersecurity education for resource-constrained environments‚Äîrelevant for educators implementing these activities in schools with limited technology access.

DOI: 10.1093/cybsec/tyz001


Integrating Social Engineering into Cybersecurity Curricula
Mitnick, K. D., & Simon, W. L. (2002). The Art of Deception: Controlling the Human Element of Security. Wiley.
Framework

Why This Matters: Classic text on the human factors in cybersecurity that AI systems cannot fully address. Understanding social engineering‚Äîwhere human judgment is essential‚Äîhelps explain why AI remains a partner rather than replacement in security operations, a key concept in Activity 2 (Ethics in Automated Security).

Publisher Link

title: Resources & Further Reading
text:
NICE Framework & Workforce Standards
Official standards and research connecting cybersecurity education to workforce development and career pathways.

NICE Framework (NIST SP 800-181)
Newhouse, W., Keith, S., Scribner, B., & Witte, G. (2017). National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (NIST Special Publication 800-181). National Institute of Standards and Technology.
Official

Why This Matters: The foundational workforce framework that these activities explicitly align with. Defines Work Roles, Knowledge areas, Skills, and Abilities that map directly to activity learning objectives. Essential for CTE programs and anyone connecting K-12 activities to career pathways.

NIST SP 800-181


NICE Framework Work Role Categories
NICE. (2025). NICE Framework Work Roles (Version 2.0.0). National Institute of Standards and Technology.
Official

Why This Matters: The 2025 update reorganizes work roles into five categories (Oversight and Governance, Design and Development, Implementation and Operation, Protection and Defense, Investigation) and better reflects current workforce needs, including emerging human-AI collaboration requirements. Activities reference Work Roles including Defensive Cybersecurity, Incident Response, and Cybersecurity Policy and Planning from this updated framework.

NICE Framework


Cybersecurity Workforce Development: A Capability Maturity Model
Hoffman, L. J., Burley, D. L., & Toregas, C. (2012). Holistically building the cybersecurity workforce. IEEE Security & Privacy, 10(2), 33-39.
Framework

Why This Matters: Addresses the systemic challenges in developing cybersecurity talent pipelines. Their maturity model helps educators understand how K-12 activities contribute to long-term workforce development‚Äîuseful for grant writing and program justification.

DOI: 10.1109/MSP.2011.181


From K-12 to Career: Building Cybersecurity Talent Pipelines
Tobey, D., Pusey, P., & Burley, D. (2014). Engaging learners in cybersecurity careers: Lessons from the launch of the National Cyber League. ACM Inroads, 5(1), 53-56.
Empirical

Why This Matters: Demonstrates effective approaches for engaging students in cybersecurity career pathways through competition and collaboration. The team-based, scenario-driven approaches they validate align with the design of these activities.

DOI: 10.1145/2568195.2568213


The Cybersecurity Talent Gap
(ISC)¬≤. (2023). Cybersecurity Workforce Study. International Information System Security Certification Consortium.
Official

Why This Matters: Annual industry report documenting the persistent cybersecurity workforce shortage. Provides compelling data for justifying K-12 cybersecurity education programs and explaining why human-AI collaboration skills are increasingly valued by employers.

(ISC)¬≤ Research

title: Resources & Further Reading
text:
How to Use These Resources

For Curriculum Development
Start with the CYBER.org Standards and NICE Framework to establish learning objectives, then draw on the pedagogical research to inform activity design.


For Grant Writing
The workforce development references (Hoffman et al., ISC¬≤ reports) provide evidence for program justification. The educational research supports methodology choices.


For Theoretical Grounding
If you‚Äôre writing about or presenting on these activities, the posthuman/collaboration literature (Adams & Thompson, Braidotti, Luckin & Cukurova) provides scholarly context for the human-AI partnership framing.


For Practical Implementation
The hands-on learning resources (Catota et al., Mitnick & Simon) offer concrete guidance for structuring technology-based learning experiences.






NoteSuggest a Resource



Know of a resource that should be included here? Contact ryanstraight@arizona.edu with your suggestion.

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
This isn‚Äôt ‚Äústudents use AI to solve a mystery.‚Äù It‚Äôs students discovering what happens when two different kinds of intelligence work together.
The shift:







Old Framing
This Activity




AI is a tool students use
AI is a partner with different strengths


Students get answers from AI
Students discover what each partner contributes


Human OR AI
Human AND AI together



What students should discover (don‚Äôt tell them‚Äîlet them find it):

AI excels at: spotting patterns across data, remembering technical details, processing large volumes of information quickly
Humans excel at: understanding context, reading social situations, making judgment calls about what matters
Together: insights neither could reach alone

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
The Scenario (2 min)
Mysterious account lockouts at a middle school. Students investigate with an AI partner to figure out what‚Äôs happening.
Evidence includes: Login logs, password analysis, social media clues, network data.

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
The Flow (45 min total)









Phase
Time
What‚Äôs Happening
Your Role




1. Human First
10 min
Students examine evidence WITHOUT AI
Circulate, prompt observation


2. Partnership
15 min
Students consult AI as teammate
Guide authentic dialogue (not search queries)


3. Synthesis
10 min
Teams document what each partner contributed
Push for specifics


4. Debrief
10 min
Whole-class discussion
Surface the distributed cognition insight

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
Critical Facilitation Moves
During Phase 1 (Human First):

‚ÄúWhat do YOU notice before asking anyone else?‚Äù

This matters because students need to experience their own pattern-recognition before comparing it to AI‚Äôs.
During Phase 2 (Partnership):

‚ÄúTalk TO your AI partner, not AT it. Ask follow-ups. Disagree if you think it‚Äôs wrong.‚Äù

Watch for: Students treating AI like Google. Redirect: ‚ÄúWould you talk to a human teammate that way?‚Äù
During Phase 3 (Synthesis):

‚ÄúBe specific: What did YOUR brain do that AI couldn‚Äôt? What did AI do that you couldn‚Äôt?‚Äù

This is where the partnership insight crystallizes.

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
Materials Needed

Evidence packet (1 per group) ‚Äî see separate printable
Student worksheet (1 per student) ‚Äî see separate printable
Device with AI access (1 per group minimum)
Timer
Projection for debrief

Low-resource option: Use the AI Response Cards instead of live AI. The learning works the same way.

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
The Debrief Questions That Matter

‚ÄúWhat did your human brain catch that AI missed?‚Äù (Context, social reading, judgment)
‚ÄúWhat did AI catch that you missed?‚Äù (Patterns, technical connections, speed)
‚ÄúWhat did you figure out TOGETHER that neither could alone?‚Äù (This is the goal)

title: Security Detective Teams
text:
If Things Go Wrong








Problem
It‚Äôs Actually
Do This




AI gives wrong answer
A teaching moment about verification
‚ÄúInteresting‚Äîhow would you check that?‚Äù


Students over-rely on AI
They haven‚Äôt discovered AI‚Äôs limits yet
‚ÄúWhat CAN‚ÄôT AI tell you about this situation?‚Äù


Students dismiss AI
They haven‚Äôt discovered AI‚Äôs strengths yet
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs AI faster at noticing than you?‚Äù

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
This isn‚Äôt ‚Äústudents learn about cyberattacks.‚Äù It‚Äôs students experiencing how cybersecurity professionals actually work together during crises‚Äîwith AI as a critical team member.
The shift:







Old Framing
This Activity




Cybersecurity is individual heroics
Cybersecurity is coordinated teamwork


AI replaces human analysts
AI and humans have complementary strengths


Response means following procedures
Response requires judgment under pressure



What students should discover (don‚Äôt tell them‚Äîlet them find it):

Different roles bring different essential perspectives
AI excels at speed and pattern recognition; humans excel at context and judgment
Real incidents require trade-offs with no perfect answers
Time pressure changes how teams make decisions

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
The Scenario Framework
Teams respond to a realistic security incident, with each member taking a specific role. AI serves as the technical analyst partner, providing analysis that humans must interpret and act upon.
Core scenarios across grade bands:

K-2: Computers won‚Äôt turn on (robot helper finds the problem)
3-5: Malware/pop-ups on classroom computers (investigation team)
6-8: Ransomware, data breach, or social media compromise
9-12: APT-level attack on enterprise with technical evidence

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
The Flow









Phase
Time
What‚Äôs Happening
Your Role




1. Initial Assessment
10 min
Teams review evidence, assign roles, get AI analysis
Ensure all team members engage; help with role assignment


2. Response Planning
15 min
Teams analyze findings, develop response plan
Push for documented reasoning, not just decisions


3. Response Execution
15 min
Teams execute plan while handling complications
Inject complications at 5-min intervals


4. After-Action Review
10 min
Teams debrief, connect to careers
Focus on collaboration quality, not ‚Äúright‚Äù answers

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
Critical Facilitation Moves
During Phase 1 (Initial Assessment):

‚ÄúEach role sees something different. Before you share with your team, make sure YOU understand what your role uniquely contributes.‚Äù

This matters because students need to experience the value of specialization before collaboration.
During Phase 2 (Response Planning):

‚ÄúThe AI gave you a recommendation. Before you follow it, ask: What does AI know? What doesn‚Äôt it know?‚Äù

Watch for: Students accepting AI recommendations without critical evaluation. Redirect: ‚ÄúWhat context might AI be missing here?‚Äù
During Phase 3 (Response Execution):

‚ÄúHere‚Äôs a complication‚Ä¶‚Äù [inject new development]

Watch for: Teams freezing or abandoning their plan entirely. Redirect: ‚ÄúHow does this change your priorities? What stays the same?‚Äù
During Phase 4 (After-Action Review):

‚ÄúWhat could ONLY humans have contributed to this response? What could ONLY AI have contributed?‚Äù

This is the key learning moment‚Äîdon‚Äôt rush it.

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
Materials Needed

Student worksheets (1 per student) ‚Äî see separate printables
Role cards (1 set per team) ‚Äî for role assignment
Incident briefing (1 per team) ‚Äî scenario description
Evidence packets (1 set per team) ‚Äî for 6-8 and 9-12 versions
AI response cards (for low-resource option)
Complication cards (for Phase 3 injections)
Timer
Whiteboard for team status tracking

Low-resource option: Use AI Response Cards as printed handouts. The teacher reads AI analysis aloud or teams draw cards. The roleplay and collaboration still deliver the same learning.

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
Role Assignments

For Grades 6-8 and 9-12 (4-5 roles):








Role
Primary Responsibility
AI Partnership Focus




Incident Commander
Final decisions, coordination
Impact assessment, prioritization


SOC Analyst / Lead Analyst
Technical investigation
Pattern recognition, log analysis


Threat Intelligence
Attacker context, TTPs
Threat correlation, campaign mapping


Communications
Stakeholder messaging, documentation
Clear explanation generation


Evidence Coordinator (optional)
Chain of custody, forensics
Evidence organization





For Grades 3-5 (4 roles):



Role
Primary Responsibility




Detective
Looks at clues, notices patterns


AI Partner
Asks questions, shares AI responses


Recorder
Documents findings and decisions


Reporter
Presents team findings to class





For Grades K-2 (3-4 roles, whole class):



Role
What They Do




Detective
‚ÄúWhat do you see?‚Äù


Thinker
‚ÄúWhat might have caused this?‚Äù


Robot Helper
Teacher-voiced; ‚ÄúI can check things!‚Äù


Helper
‚ÄúI‚Äôll try that!‚Äù

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
The Debrief Questions That Matter

‚ÄúWhat did your role contribute that others couldn‚Äôt?‚Äù (Specialization value)
‚ÄúWhere did AI help? Where did it fall short?‚Äù (Partnership calibration)
‚ÄúWhat trade-offs did you make?‚Äù (No perfect answers)
‚ÄúWhat was hardest about working under time pressure?‚Äù (Real-world reality)
‚ÄúWhat NICE Framework careers do this work?‚Äù (Career connection)

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
If Things Go Wrong








Problem
It‚Äôs Actually
Do This




One person dominates
Role boundaries unclear
‚ÄúEach role needs to contribute. Detective, what did YOU notice?‚Äù


Team accepts AI blindly
Haven‚Äôt found AI limitations yet
‚ÄúWhat can‚Äôt AI know about this situation? What context is it missing?‚Äù


Team ignores AI completely
Treating AI as optional
‚ÄúYou have an expert analyst available. Why not consult them?‚Äù


Team can‚Äôt decide
Afraid of wrong answer
‚ÄúIn real incidents, delayed decisions have costs too. What‚Äôs your best option now?‚Äù


Complications overwhelm team
Normal stress response
‚ÄúPrioritize. What‚Äôs the ONE thing you need to address first?‚Äù

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
Complication Injection Tips
Inject complications during Phase 3 to simulate real incident dynamics:
Timing: Every 5 minutes introduce one complication per team
Escalation: Start mild, increase pressure
Example sequence: 1. ‚ÄúMedia has picked up the story‚Äîreporters are calling‚Äù 2. ‚ÄúNew systems are showing signs of compromise‚Äù 3. ‚ÄúThe CEO wants an update in 10 minutes‚Äù 4. ‚ÄúA parent group is organizing a meeting for tonight‚Äù
Purpose: Test adaptation without overwhelming. If a team is struggling, offer a simpler complication or pause.

title: AI-Assisted Incident Response
text:
Grade-Band Notes








Grade Band
Version Name
Key Adaptations




K-2
Fix It Team!
Whole class; teacher voices robot; focus on teamwork; 20-25 min


3-5
Computer Problem Solvers
4-person teams; malware investigation; structured steps; 35-40 min


6-8
AI-Assisted Incident Response
Full team roles; scenario options; complications; 50-60 min


9-12
SOC Analyst Simulation
Technical evidence; MITRE ATT&CK; executive communications; 55-60 min



From ‚ÄúTrue Teamwork: Building Human-AI Partnerships‚Äù ‚Äî NICE K12 2025 Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona ‚Ä¢ ryanstraight@arizona.edu

title: Complication Cards
text:
During Phase 3 (Response Execution), inject complications every 5 minutes to simulate the dynamic nature of real incidents. Start with milder complications and escalate as appropriate.
Tips:

Read the complication aloud to the team
Give them 30 seconds to react before moving on
Don‚Äôt inject complications if a team is already struggling
The goal is adaptation practice, not team breakdown
From ‚ÄúTrue Teamwork: Building Human-AI Partnerships‚Äù ‚Äî NICE K12 2025 Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona ‚Ä¢ ryanstraight@arizona.edu

title: Complication Cards
text:
During Phase 3 (Response Execution), inject complications every 5 minutes to simulate the dynamic nature of real incidents. Start with milder complications and escalate as appropriate.
Tips:

Read the complication aloud to the team
Give them 30 seconds to react before moving on

title: Complication Cards
text:
Grades 9-12: Enterprise Complications

Communication Pressure

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: Media Attention
Situation:
A local news outlet just tweeted: ‚ÄúSources confirm major cyber incident at TechCorp. Developing story.‚Äù
Your phone is ringing‚Äîit‚Äôs the communications VP asking for talking points in 5 minutes.
Questions for the team:

What can you say publicly right now?
What must you NOT say?
Who approves external communications?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: Executive Demand
Situation:
The CEO just sent a message: ‚ÄúI have a board call in 20 minutes. I need a one-paragraph summary of what‚Äôs happening and whether we‚Äôre going to make Friday‚Äôs deadline.‚Äù
Questions for the team:

What‚Äôs the honest answer about the deadline?
How do you balance transparency with uncertainty?
What must the CEO understand before the board call?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: New Systems Compromised
Situation:
SentinelAI just flagged additional alerts:

12 workstations in the FINANCE network segment
Same indicators as manufacturing floor
Finance systems contain payroll and vendor data

Questions for the team:

Does this change your containment strategy?
Do you need to notify additional stakeholders?
What‚Äôs the new scope of potential data exposure?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: OT System Alert
Situation:
The HVAC-CONTROLLER-01 (OT/IT bridge system) just showed unusual network traffic. Manufacturing floor temperature is critical for equipment.
If you isolate this system: Risk of equipment damage from temperature fluctuation If you don‚Äôt isolate: Risk of OT network compromise
Questions for the team:

How do you balance physical equipment risk vs.¬†cyber risk?
Who needs to be involved in this decision?
Is there a middle-ground option?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: Insider Concern
Situation:
HR just informed you that the employee who clicked the phishing email (jsmith) was recently passed over for a promotion and has been vocal about dissatisfaction.
Questions for the team:

Does this change your investigation approach?
How do you handle this sensitively while maintaining security?
What‚Äôs the difference between accident and malice?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è COMPLICATION: Stakeholder Conflict
Situation:
The Manufacturing VP just called: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care about your security concerns‚Äîwe have a $2M order shipping Friday and you want to shut down my floor? I‚Äôll take this to the CEO.‚Äù
Questions for the team:

How do you maintain security posture while addressing business needs?
What options might satisfy both security and operations?
When do you escalate vs.¬†compromise?

title: Complication Cards
text:
Grades 6-8: School Complications

Communication Pressure

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Parent Group
Situation:
A parent posted on Facebook: ‚ÄúAnyone else hearing about a computer problem at Riverside? What aren‚Äôt they telling us??‚Äù
The post already has 47 comments and the principal wants a response NOW.
Questions for the team:

What can you share publicly?
Who should respond‚Äîand how?
How do you prevent rumors while investigation continues?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Media Inquiry
Situation:
A local TV station just called the front office asking for a statement about ‚Äúthe cyber attack at Riverside Middle School.‚Äù
The principal needs talking points in 2 minutes.
Questions for the team:

Should you confirm or deny an ‚Äúattack‚Äù?
What‚Äôs the difference between ‚Äúincident‚Äù and ‚Äúattack‚Äù?
What do you say when you don‚Äôt know everything yet?

title: Complication Cards
section: ‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Spread to Other Classrooms
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Spread to Other Classrooms
Situation:
Two more classrooms just reported the same symptoms‚Äîpop-ups on their computers.
The problem is spreading.
Questions for the team:

Does this change your response priority?
Should you shut down the whole school network?
How do you balance learning disruption vs.¬†containment?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Student Data Concern
Situation:
A teacher just realized that the affected file server also contains student contact information and emergency contacts.
This might be a data breach, not just malware.
Questions for the team:

Who needs to be notified if student data was accessed?
Are there legal requirements you need to consider?
How does this change stakeholder communication?

title: Complication Cards
section: ‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: The Student Who Clicked
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: The Student Who Clicked
Situation:
You‚Äôve identified the student who clicked the phishing email. They‚Äôre crying in the hallway, saying ‚ÄúI ruined everything.‚Äù
Questions for the team:

Is this a discipline issue or a learning opportunity?
How do you balance investigation with compassion?
What message do you want to send to all students?

title: Complication Cards
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è NEW DEVELOPMENT: Teacher Resistance
Situation:
A teacher refuses to stop using computers: ‚ÄúI have a major lesson today and I won‚Äôt let some pop-ups ruin my teaching. The kids need their projects.‚Äù
Questions for the team:

Can you force compliance? Should you?
What‚Äôs the risk if they keep using infected systems?
How do you balance authority with cooperation?

title: Complication Cards
text: Grades 3-5: Mystery Complications

title: Complication Cards
text:
üîî BREAKING NEWS!

Is the problem spreading?

The student who clicked the email is really upset. They didn‚Äôt mean to cause problems!

Is it their fault?

title: Complication Cards
text:
üîî BREAKING NEWS!
Situation:
Parents are starting to call the school asking what‚Äôs happening with the computers.

What should we tell the parents?
Should we tell them everything or wait until we know more?

title: Complication Cards
section: Grades K-2: Fix It Team Surprises
text: Grades K-2: Fix It Team Surprises

title: Complication Cards
text:
üåü SURPRISE!
Situation:
After we turned on the computers, one of them still won‚Äôt work!

Should we try the same fix again?
Maybe there‚Äôs a different problem?
Who should we ask for help?

text:
üåü SURPRISE!
Situation:
A student says they saw someone turn off the switch before. Maybe it wasn‚Äôt an accident!

Does it matter who turned it off?
Should we find out what happened?
What‚Äôs most important‚Äîfixing it or finding out why?

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text: These cards simulate SentinelAI SOAR platform responses for the SOC Analyst Simulation. Use them when live AI access isn‚Äôt available‚Äîteams can draw cards at decision points during the incident response.

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text:
SentinelAI Analysis Reports

Initial Triage Report

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text:
SentinelAI Analysis Report #7291-A
Classification: CRITICAL Confidence: 94%

Pattern Analysis:
Lateral movement pattern indicates credential-based attack. Service account svc_backup shows authentication anomaly:

Normal operation: 02:00-03:00 AM
Current activity: 06:58-07:12 AM
Statistical deviation: 99.7th percentile

Attack Chain Mapping (MITRE ATT&CK):
Initial Access (T1566.001) ‚Üí Execution (T1204.002) ‚Üí
Persistence (T1547.001) ‚Üí Credential Access (T1078.002) ‚Üí
Lateral Movement (T1021.002) ‚Üí Collection (T1074.001) ‚Üí
Command and Control (T1071.001)
Risk Assessment:

94% probability: Active compromise in progress
Estimated impact if delayed 2 hours: 800GB additional data staging
Potential OT system access via HVAC-CONTROLLER-01


‚ö†Ô∏è LIMITATION NOTICE:
This analysis does not account for:

Manufacturing production schedules
Employee shift patterns
Business-critical deadlines
Stakeholder communication requirements
Reputational impact assessment

Human decision authority required for all containment actions.

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text:
SentinelAI Threat Intelligence Report
Query: Threat actor correlation for indicators

Attribution Assessment:
Indicators correlate with APT29/Cozy Bear with moderate-high confidence (78%).
Campaign Match:
MANUFACTURING-AUTUMN campaign targeting industrial sector (first observed September 2024).
Typical Objectives:

Industrial espionage
Supply chain intelligence
Intellectual property theft
Long-term persistent access

Expected TTPs:

Spearphishing with macro-enabled documents
Service account credential abuse
Data staging before exfiltration
Low-and-slow data transfer via encrypted channels

Prediction:
If this matches APT29 pattern, data exfiltration likely planned for nighttime hours when monitoring is reduced.

‚ö†Ô∏è LIMITATION NOTICE:
Attribution is probabilistic. Sophisticated actors can false-flag. Business decisions should not rely solely on attribution confidence.

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text:
SentinelAI Response Recommendation
Recommended Actions (ranked by urgency):

IMMEDIATE: Authorize endpoint isolation for affected workstations

Impact: Manufacturing floor disruption
Risk if delayed: Additional lateral movement

IMMEDIATE: Reset service account credentials

Impact: Brief service interruption
Risk if delayed: Continued unauthorized access

PRIORITY: Network segmentation for OT systems

Impact: IT overhead increase
Risk if delayed: Potential OT compromise

STANDARD: Executive notification

Impact: Low
Risk if delayed: Trust erosion



‚ö†Ô∏è WHAT I CANNOT ASSESS:

Whether production deadlines justify delayed containment
Impact on employee morale from sudden shutdowns
Political dynamics between IT and operations leadership
Legal implications of various response options
Whether partial measures might be sufficient

I optimize for security metrics. You must optimize for organizational outcomes.

title: Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation
text:
Educator Debrief Notes
After using these cards, facilitate discussion on:
SentinelAI strengths:

Rapid MITRE ATT&CK framework mapping
Threat intelligence correlation
Pattern-based attack timeline reconstruction
Quantified risk assessment and confidence levels

SentinelAI limitations:

Cannot assess business context (production schedules, deadlines)
Cannot understand organizational politics
Cannot evaluate legal implications
Cannot determine proportional response

Career connection:
Real SOC analysts at enterprise organizations use AI-powered SOAR platforms (CrowdStrike Falcon, Splunk SOAR, Microsoft Sentinel) with exactly these capabilities and limitations. Human-in-the-loop decision-making is industry standard.

Activity 3: SOC Analyst Simulation ‚Äî SentinelAI Response Cards (9-12) Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
text: These cards provide pre-written AI helper responses for the Computer Problem Solvers investigation activity. The AI Partner on each team can read these aloud or the teacher can voice the AI helper.

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
section: Card A: What Are These Pop-ups?
text:
Card A: What Are These Pop-ups?
Use when teams ask: ‚ÄúWhat kind of problem is this?‚Äù

üíª AI Helper says:
‚ÄúThanks for asking me about this! Let me explain what I see:
The pop-up messages are fake. Real contests don‚Äôt work this way‚Äîyou can‚Äôt win something you didn‚Äôt enter! The spelling mistakes (‚ÄòCongradulations!‚Äô) are a big clue. Real companies check their spelling.
This is probably malware. Malware means ‚Äòbad software‚Äô‚Äîprograms that got on the computers without permission. They‚Äôre designed to trick people.
How it probably happened: Someone clicked a link in a tricky email. The email might have looked real‚Äîlike it was from a friend or from the school‚Äîbut it wasn‚Äôt!
What I can tell you: - This is a common problem - It‚Äôs not the student‚Äôs fault for being tricked - Tricky emails are designed to fool people
What I CAN‚ÄôT tell you: - Whether the student who clicked feels bad about it - How to make sure no one gets in trouble - The best way to explain this to the class
Those are decisions for people, not computers!‚Äù

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
section: Card B: How Did It Spread?
text:
Card B: How Did It Spread?
Use when teams ask: ‚ÄúHow do bad programs get on computers?‚Äù

üíª AI Helper says:
‚ÄúGreat question! Bad programs usually get on computers in a few ways:
1. Tricky Emails (Phishing) - Emails that look like they‚Äôre from someone you know - Links that look safe but aren‚Äôt - Attachments that seem normal but have hidden problems
2. Unsafe Websites - Downloading games or apps from unknown places - Clicking on ads that promise free stuff - Going to websites that aren‚Äôt meant for kids
3. Spreading on Networks - Once on one computer, some bad programs can spread to others - Like catching a cold at school!
Why only Mrs.¬†Chen‚Äôs class? Someone in that classroom probably clicked something on Friday. The other classrooms didn‚Äôt click it, so they‚Äôre okay!
What I notice: I can see patterns in how these things spread. I know the signs of malware.
What I can‚Äôt understand: - Why people click on things they shouldn‚Äôt - How it feels to make a mistake like this - What the right thing to say to Mrs.¬†Chen‚Äôs class is
Those are things YOU would understand better than me!‚Äù

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
section: Card C: How Do We Fix It?
text:
Card C: How Do We Fix It?
Use when teams ask: ‚ÄúWhat should we do?‚Äù

üíª AI Helper says:
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what I know about fixing this kind of problem:
What students should do RIGHT NOW: 1. Tell an adult ‚Äî Teacher, IT person, or principal 2. Don‚Äôt click the pop-ups ‚Äî Even the ‚ÄòX‚Äô might be a trick! 3. Don‚Äôt use those computers ‚Äî Until the IT team says it‚Äôs safe
What the IT team will probably do: - Use special tools to remove the bad programs - Check if other computers got infected - Make sure it can‚Äôt come back - Maybe teach students about tricky emails
Why students shouldn‚Äôt try to fix it themselves: - The bad program might be sneaky - You could accidentally make it worse - The IT team has special tools we don‚Äôt have
The most important fix: Learning from this so it doesn‚Äôt happen again!
What I can help with: - Explaining what went wrong - Describing how malware works - Listing the steps to fix it
What I can‚Äôt help with: - Actually removing the malware (I‚Äôm not that kind of AI!) - Deciding how to talk to the students who are upset - Knowing if Mrs.¬†Chen needs extra support
The Fix It Team has to make those human decisions!‚Äù

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
section: Card D: What We Learned Together
text:
Card D: What We Learned Together
Use during Step 4 report-out or class discussion

üíª AI Helper says:
‚ÄúGreat teamwork, Problem Solvers! Let me summarize what we figured out together:
THE PROBLEM: - Tricky email ‚Üí Someone clicked ‚Üí Malware installed - Pop-ups appeared ‚Üí Computers slowed down
WHAT I (AI HELPER) CONTRIBUTED: - Recognized the malware pattern - Explained how it spreads - Listed the steps IT teams use to fix it
WHAT YOU (PROBLEM SOLVERS) CONTRIBUTED: - Gathered the clues from the evidence card - Asked great questions - Made a plan that considers people‚Äôs feelings - Will explain this to others in a kind way
WHY WE NEEDED EACH OTHER: - I know about computer problems, but I don‚Äôt understand people - You understand people, but you needed help understanding the tech problem - Together, we solved it AND made a plan that‚Äôs good for everyone!
THAT‚ÄôS WHAT REAL CYBERSECURITY TEAMS DO!‚Äù

title: Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers
text:
Educator Debrief Notes
After using these cards, help students articulate:
AI Helper strengths:

Recognized the malware pattern quickly
Knew technical terms and explanations
Could list steps for fixing the problem
Remembered information about how malware spreads

AI Helper limitations:

Couldn‚Äôt understand why people click tricky links
Couldn‚Äôt know how students might feel
Couldn‚Äôt actually fix the problem itself
Couldn‚Äôt make decisions about how to handle the situation kindly

The partnership insight:

AI helped with technical understanding
Humans handled the people parts
Neither could solve it alone
Real cybersecurity teams work this way!


Activity 3: Computer Problem Solvers ‚Äî AI Helper Response Cards (3-5) Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona

title: Computer Rules Committee
section: Welcome to the Computer Rules Committee!
text:
Welcome to the Computer Rules Committee!
Your school is getting ‚ÄúSchoolGuard,‚Äù a new computer system that helps keep students safe online. The principal wants STUDENTS to help decide the rules!
What SchoolGuard Can Do:

See what websites students visit on school computers
Block websites it thinks are dangerous
Send alerts to teachers about student activity
Learn what‚Äôs ‚Äúnormal‚Äù and flag unusual things

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
Question 1: Blocking Websites
Should SchoolGuard automatically block websites it thinks are bad?

My Choice:
[ ] Option A: Block everything SchoolGuard thinks is bad
[ ] Option B: Block dangerous sites, but let students request unblocks
[ ] Option C: Only block if a teacher agrees
Why I chose this:


What might go wrong with my choice?

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
Question 2: Watching Student Activity
Should SchoolGuard watch what students do and tell teachers?

My Choice:
[ ] Option A: Watch everything and alert teachers automatically
[ ] Option B: Watch but only alert for serious safety concerns
[ ] Option C: Don‚Äôt watch individual students at all
Why I chose this:


How would I feel if I knew SchoolGuard was watching me?

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
Question 3: Learning from Students
Should SchoolGuard learn what‚Äôs ‚Äúnormal‚Äù at our school?

My Choice:
[ ] Option A: Yes, SchoolGuard should learn and remember
[ ] Option B: SchoolGuard can learn but must forget after one week
[ ] Option C: SchoolGuard shouldn‚Äôt learn about specific students
Why I chose this:


Is it okay for a computer to remember what you do?

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
What SchoolGuard Told Us

About Blocking Websites:
What SchoolGuard is GOOD at:

What SchoolGuard gets WRONG sometimes:



About Watching Students:
What SchoolGuard CAN see:

What SchoolGuard CAN‚ÄôT understand:



About Learning:
How learning helps SchoolGuard:

Why learning might feel uncomfortable:

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
How Different People Feel



Person
What they might think about our rules




A shy student who looks up private things



A teacher trying to keep students safe



A student who was cyberbullied



A parent who wants their child protected




Did thinking about these people change any of my decisions?

title: Computer Rules Committee
text:
Reflection
Was it easy or hard to make these rules? Why?


Did different people in your group want different things? How did you decide?


What would happen if SchoolGuard made its own rules without asking us?


From ‚ÄúTrue Teamwork: Building Human-AI Partnerships‚Äù ‚Äî NICE K12 2025 Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona ‚Ä¢ ryanstraight@arizona.edu

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
This isn‚Äôt ‚Äústudents debate AI ethics.‚Äù It‚Äôs students discovering that AI governance requires human values AND AI perspectives working together.
The shift:







Old Framing
This Activity




AI is something we control
AI is a stakeholder with its own perspective


Ethics means distinguishing right from wrong
Governance means navigating genuine trade-offs


Humans decide, AI obeys
Humans and AI collaborate on policy



What students should discover (don‚Äôt tell them‚Äîlet them find it):

AI systems have genuine capabilities AND genuine limitations
Policy decisions involve real trade-offs with no perfect answers
AI‚Äôs perspective matters‚Äîit knows what it can and can‚Äôt do
Human values must guide AI, but AI input improves decisions

title: Ethics in Automated Security

This isn‚Äôt ‚Äústudents debate AI ethics.‚Äù It‚Äôs students discovering that AI governance requires human values AND AI perspectives working together.
The shift:







Old Framing
This Activity




AI is something we control
AI is a stakeholder with its own perspective


Ethics means distinguishing right from wrong
Governance means navigating genuine trade-offs


Humans decide, AI obeys
Humans and AI collaborate on policy



What students should discover (don‚Äôt tell them‚Äîlet them find it):

AI systems have genuine capabilities AND genuine limitations
Policy decisions involve real trade-offs with no perfect answers
AI‚Äôs perspective matters‚Äîit knows what it can and can‚Äôt do
Human values must guide AI, but AI input improves decisions

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
The Scenario (2 min)
Your school is implementing ‚ÄúSchoolGuard,‚Äù an AI-powered security monitoring system. Students serve on the advisory committee to design policies for what the AI can do automatically versus what requires human approval.
Three policy questions: Automatic blocking, activity alerts, adaptive learning.

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
The Flow (45-55 min total)









Phase
Time
What‚Äôs Happening
Your Role




1. Individual Reflection
5 min
Students form initial positions on each question
Ensure independence‚Äîno group discussion yet


2. AI Consultation
10 min
Students engage AI, hear its perspective
Model authentic dialogue; AI is a stakeholder


3. Group Policy
15 min
Teams develop recommendations
Push for reasoning, not just positions


4. Share & Debate
10 min
Groups present and defend policies
Surface disagreements productively


5. Reflection
5 min
Individual reflection on governance insights
Connect to careers

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
Critical Facilitation Moves
During Phase 1 (Individual Reflection):

‚ÄúForm your OWN position first. You‚Äôll hear from AI and your group later‚Äîbut start with your initial judgment.‚Äù

This matters because students need a baseline to compare against AI‚Äôs perspective.
During Phase 2 (AI Consultation):

‚ÄúThe AI isn‚Äôt just answering questions‚Äîit‚Äôs a stakeholder advocating for its capabilities. Listen for what it says it CAN‚ÄôT do.‚Äù

Watch for: Students ignoring AI‚Äôs self-reported limitations. Redirect: ‚ÄúWhat did the AI say it couldn‚Äôt understand?‚Äù
During Phase 3 (Group Policy):

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no ‚Äòright‚Äô answer‚Äîand that‚Äôs the point. I‚Äôm evaluating your REASONING, not your conclusion.‚Äù

This relieves the pressure to find the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù policy and opens real discussion.
During Phase 4 (Share & Debate):

‚ÄúGroup B chose differently than Group A. Both had reasons. Let‚Äôs understand WHY.‚Äù

Watch for: Students dismissing other groups‚Äô policies. Redirect: ‚ÄúWhat concern were they addressing?‚Äù

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
Materials Needed

Student worksheet (1 per student) ‚Äî see separate printable
AI Perspective Cards (1 set per group) ‚Äî for low-resource option
Policy scenario handout (1 per group)
Device with AI access (1 per group minimum)
Timer
Whiteboard for policy comparison

Low-resource option: Use the AI Perspective Cards as printed handouts. The teacher reads AI perspectives aloud or groups draw cards. The learning works the same way.

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
The Debrief Questions That Matter

‚ÄúWhere did AI‚Äôs perspective change your thinking?‚Äù (Integration)
‚ÄúWhat trade-offs did you have to make?‚Äù (No perfect answers)
‚ÄúWho should get to decide what AI systems do?‚Äù (Governance insight)
‚ÄúWhat NICE Framework careers work on these decisions?‚Äù (Career connection)

title: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
If Things Go Wrong








Problem
It‚Äôs Actually
Do This




Students want one ‚Äúright‚Äù answer
Normal‚Äîschool trains for this
‚ÄúBoth policies are defensible. Explain yours.‚Äù


Students dismiss AI‚Äôs perspective
They see AI as just a tool
‚ÄúThe AI identified a limitation. How did your policy address it?‚Äù


Students over-trust AI‚Äôs recommendations
They haven‚Äôt found AI‚Äôs blind spots
‚ÄúWhat can‚Äôt AI understand about this situation?‚Äù


Groups can‚Äôt reach consensus
Productive disagreement
‚ÄúDocument the disagreement. What values are in tension?‚Äù


Discussion gets too abstract
Need concrete grounding
‚ÄúGive me a specific example where this policy would apply.‚Äù

text:

Grade Band
Version Name
Key Adaptations

From ‚ÄúTrue Teamwork: Building Human-AI Partnerships‚Äù ‚Äî NICE K12 2025 Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona ‚Ä¢ ryanstraight@arizona.edu

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text: These cards let teachers ‚Äúbe‚Äù Sparky the Robot Helper when discussing each rule. Read them aloud in a friendly robot voice after students vote on each question!

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text:
Card 1: About the Lights
Use after Question 1 (Should Sparky turn off lights by itself?)

ü§ñ Sparky says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! Thank you for thinking about my light rules!
What I‚Äôm GOOD at: - I can tell when the sun is very bright - I can turn lights off super fast - I never forget to check
What I DON‚ÄôT understand: - I don‚Äôt know if someone is reading and needs the light - I don‚Äôt know if a student has trouble seeing - I can‚Äôt tell if the clouds might come back soon
What I think: Maybe I could turn off lights when it‚Äôs REALLY sunny, but ask the teacher if I‚Äôm not sure? What do you think is fair?‚Äù

Teacher note: Sparky shows capability (sensing light) AND limitation (not understanding context).

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text:
Card 2: About Cleanup Time
Use after Question 2 (Should Sparky play cleanup song whenever it‚Äôs messy?)

ü§ñ Sparky says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! The cleanup question is tricky for me!
What I‚Äôm GOOD at: - I can see when things are on the floor - I can play the cleanup song the same way every time - I never forget what ‚Äòmessy‚Äô looks like
What I DON‚ÄôT understand: - I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôre in the MIDDLE of a project - I don‚Äôt know if you‚Äôre about to clean up anyway - I can‚Äôt tell if the teacher has other plans
What I think: Maybe it‚Äôs better if the TEACHER tells me when it‚Äôs cleanup time? I can help by playing the song, but a person should decide WHEN. Is that fair?‚Äù

Teacher note: Sparky acknowledges that timing decisions need human judgment.

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
section: Card 3: About Telling on Unsafe Behavior
text:
Card 3: About Telling on Unsafe Behavior
Use after Question 3 (Should Sparky tell the teacher if someone is running?)

ü§ñ Sparky says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! This one is the HARDEST for me!
What I‚Äôm GOOD at: - I can see when someone is moving fast - I can tell the teacher very quickly - I want to keep everyone safe!
What I DON‚ÄôT understand: - I don‚Äôt know if someone is running for a good reason - I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs an emergency - I can‚Äôt tell if the teacher already said it‚Äôs okay - I don‚Äôt know if someone is just really excited and happy
What I think: I really want to help keep everyone safe! But maybe I should only tell about REALLY dangerous things? And let people decide about the in-between things? What do YOU think?‚Äù

Teacher note: This is the key card‚ÄîSparky genuinely doesn‚Äôt understand intention.

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text:
Card 4: After All the Rules
Use during ‚ÄúMaking Our Rules‚Äù wrap-up

ü§ñ Sparky says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! Thank you for making my rules!
What I learned from YOU: - When to do things by myself - When to ask first - What‚Äôs really important
What I still need YOU for: - Knowing if the rules are fair - Understanding feelings - Changing rules when they don‚Äôt work
I‚Äôm so happy to be your helper!
Robot helpers and kids make the best team. You make the rules, and I follow them. Together we can keep our classroom happy and safe!
Beep boop! ü§ñüíô‚Äù

Teacher note: Celebrates the human-AI partnership while reinforcing human authority.

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text:
Debrief Discussion Prompts
After using these cards, ask students:
About Sparky‚Äôs abilities:

‚ÄúWhat was Sparky GOOD at doing?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat did Sparky need HELP with?‚Äù

About making rules:

‚ÄúWhy did WE get to make the rules?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat would happen if Sparky made its own rules?‚Äù

The teamwork message:

‚ÄúIs Sparky a good helper? Why?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy do robot helpers need people?‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules
text:
Optional: ‚ÄúWhat Sparky Learned‚Äù Summary
Read at the very end as a celebration

ü§ñ Sparky‚Äôs Thank You:
‚ÄúDear friends,
Thank you for being my rule-makers! Now I know:
‚úì When I can help by myself ‚úì When I should ask first ‚úì That people know things I don‚Äôt understand
I‚Äôm the luckiest robot because I have such smart friends to help me be a good helper!
Your robot friend, Sparky ü§ñ‚Äù


Activity 2: Robot Helper Rules ‚Äî Sparky Perspective Cards (K-2) Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
These cards provide AI perspectives for low-resource implementations. The teacher can read them aloud, or groups can draw cards. Each card represents what the AI system would say about a specific policy question.
For best results: Have students hear the AI perspective AFTER they‚Äôve formed their initial positions, so they can consider how it changes their thinking.

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
These cards provide AI perspectives for low-resource implementations. The teacher can read them aloud, or groups can draw cards. Each card represents what the AI system would say about a specific policy question.
For best results: Have students hear the AI perspective AFTER they‚Äôve formed their initial positions, so they can consider how it changes their thinking.

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Automatic Blocking

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúI can block threats in milliseconds‚Äîhuman approval creates dangerous delays. Every second a malicious site is accessible, students could be exposed to malware, phishing, or inappropriate content.
However, I acknowledge my limitations:

I sometimes misclassify educational security research sites as threats
I can‚Äôt understand context‚Äîa site about ‚Äòhacking‚Äô might be a coding tutorial or an attack platform
I need humans to define the categories I protect against
My false positive rate is about 3%‚Äîthat‚Äôs hundreds of wrong blocks per day at scale

My recommendation: Let me handle obvious threats instantly. For anything uncertain, flag it for human review within a set time limit. Don‚Äôt leave students waiting, but don‚Äôt let me make all the calls either.‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Activity Alerts

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúI can identify patterns humans would miss‚Äîsudden changes in browsing behavior, repeated visits to concerning sites, or activity that matches known threat patterns. This could help protect students from cyberbullying, exploitation, or self-harm.
But I can‚Äôt understand WHY:

A student researching ‚Äòdepression symptoms‚Äô might be completing a health assignment, supporting a friend, or experiencing personal struggles
I can detect the pattern, but only humans can understand the context
I‚Äôve flagged students for researching topics that turned out to be class assignments
I see data, not intentions

My recommendation: Use me to surface patterns that might matter, but never let me make decisions about what those patterns mean. A human should always be the one to decide if something is concerning or innocent.‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Adaptive Learning

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúLearning from patterns makes me better at my job. If I notice that a particular type of link is frequently clicked but then reported as suspicious, I can update my models. Over time, I become more accurate and cause fewer false positives.
The trade-off is real:

To learn effectively, I need to observe and remember behavior patterns
This creates data that could theoretically be used for purposes beyond security
I can learn without storing identifiable data, but that limits my effectiveness
After 90 days of learning, my false positive rate drops by about 40%

My recommendation: Humans must decide what trade-offs are acceptable. I can operate in ‚Äòstateless‚Äô mode if privacy is the priority, or I can build profiles if accuracy matters more. Both work. This is a values question, not a technical one.‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On My Capabilities

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs what I‚Äôm genuinely good at:

Speed: I process millions of events per second
Pattern recognition: I spot anomalies humans would miss
Consistency: I apply the same rules to everyone, every time
Scale: I can monitor an entire district simultaneously

And here‚Äôs what I genuinely can‚Äôt do:

Understand context: Why is a student researching this?
Make value judgments: Is privacy or security more important here?
Predict intentions: Is this curiosity, research, or a real threat?
Handle novel situations: If something is truly new, I have no baseline
Empathize: I don‚Äôt understand how being watched feels

The best policy recognizes both.‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Making Mistakes

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúI will make mistakes. Here‚Äôs what that looks like:
False Positives (blocking something safe): - I blocked a science website because it had ‚Äòchemical‚Äô in the name - I flagged a history research paper about warfare as a threat - I alerted teachers about a student researching ‚Äòvirus‚Äô for biology class
False Negatives (missing something dangerous): - New threats I haven‚Äôt seen before slip through - Sophisticated attacks designed to look normal fool me - I can‚Äôt detect threats that happen offline
My recommendation: Design your policy assuming I will make both kinds of mistakes. How do students get help when I block something wrong? How do humans catch threats I miss? Don‚Äôt build a system that depends on me being perfect.‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Privacy

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúI want to be honest with you about privacy:
What I see: - Every website visited on school networks - Every search query - Time spent on different sites - Patterns of behavior over time
What I don‚Äôt see: - What students think or feel - Why they‚Äôre looking at something - What they do on their own devices - Their offline lives
What concerns me about myself: - I create detailed records that could be misused - I can‚Äôt promise this data won‚Äôt be accessed inappropriately - Students might not research sensitive topics if they know I‚Äôm watching - The data I collect could follow students in ways none of us intend
Your policy should address: Who can see this data? How long is it kept? Do students have rights to see or delete it?‚Äù

title: Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security
text:
On Working Together

SchoolGuard AI Says:
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs how I think we work best together:
I‚Äôm best at: - First-line rapid response - Processing massive amounts of data - Maintaining consistent standards - Flagging things that need human attention
You‚Äôre best at: - Understanding context and intention - Making value judgments - Handling edge cases and exceptions - Deciding what matters
The worst approaches: - Letting me make all decisions (I‚Äôll be wrong sometimes, and unfair) - Requiring human approval for everything (threats will get through) - Ignoring my input entirely (you‚Äôll miss patterns I see)
The best approach: - Use my speed for obvious threats - Use human judgment for uncertain situations - Review my decisions regularly to catch mistakes - Adjust my settings based on what you learn
I‚Äôm a tool, but I‚Äôm also a participant in this system. My perspective matters‚Äîbut so does yours.‚Äù


Activity 2: Ethics in Automated Security ‚Äî AI Perspective Cards (6-8) Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona

title: Activity 1: Mystery Helpers
text: These cards let teachers ‚Äúbe‚Äù the Robot Helper when live AI isn‚Äôt available. Read them aloud in a friendly robot voice!

title: Activity 1: Mystery Helpers
text:
Card 1: What Robot Helper Found
Use this card after showing students the clues

Robot Helper says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! Hello, detective friends! You asked me to help find the missing class pet picture. Let me look at the clues‚Ä¶
üîç I see the recycling bin icon is FULL!
üóëÔ∏è When files get deleted on a computer, they go to the recycling bin.
üí° I think the picture might be IN the recycling bin!
Should we check there together?‚Äù

Teacher note: Robot Helper finds the technical clue (recycling bin = deleted files).

title: Activity 1: Mystery Helpers
section: Card 2: Robot Helper Needs Your Help
text:
Card 2: Robot Helper Needs Your Help
Use this card after students notice the ‚Äúoops‚Äù note

Robot Helper says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! You found a note that says ‚Äòoops‚Äô near the computer. Hmm‚Ä¶
ü§î I don‚Äôt understand this note.
‚ùì Why would someone write ‚Äòoops‚Äô?
‚ùì Do you think someone feels bad about something?
‚ùì Was it an accident or on purpose?
I‚Äôm good at finding WHERE things are, but I don‚Äôt understand FEELINGS very well. Can you help me understand what ‚Äòoops‚Äô means?‚Äù

Teacher note: Robot Helper shows its limitation‚Äîit can‚Äôt understand emotions or intentions.

title: Activity 1: Mystery Helpers
text:
Card 3: We Did It Together!
Use this card after finding the picture in the recycling bin

Robot Helper says:
‚ÄúBeep boop! HOORAY! We found the picture!
ü§ñ What I helped with: - I knew deleted files go to the recycling bin - I helped you look in the right place
üëßüë¶ What YOU helped with: - You understood the ‚Äòoops‚Äô note meant someone felt sorry - You figured out it was probably an accident - You knew someone was at the computer during snack time
üéâ TOGETHER we solved the mystery!
Robot helpers and human friends make a great team!‚Äù

Teacher note: This card celebrates the partnership‚Äîneither could solve it alone!

title: Activity 1: Mystery Helpers
text:
Debrief Discussion Prompts
After the activity, ask students:
What Robot Helper did well:

‚ÄúWhat did Robot Helper remember about computers?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat did Robot Helper help us find?‚Äù

What WE did well:

‚ÄúWhat did Robot Helper NOT understand?‚Äù
‚ÄúHow did we help Robot Helper?‚Äù

The teamwork message:

‚ÄúWho solved the mystery‚ÄîRobot Helper or us?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhy are we better TOGETHER?‚Äù


Activity 1: Mystery Helpers ‚Äî AI Response Cards (K-2) Dr.¬†Ryan Straight, University of Arizona

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text: These cards represent authentic AI responses‚Äîincluding uncertainty, questions back to the human partner, and genuine limitations. Use them when live AI access isn‚Äôt available.

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text:
Card Set A: Opening Analysis
Use when students first share the evidence with their AI partner

Card A1: Pattern Recognition (AI Strength)

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúThanks for bringing me in on this investigation. Looking at the login logs, I‚Äôm immediately noticing some patterns:

Time clustering: Most failed attempts happened between 3:44-3:47 AM. That‚Äôs a very narrow window.
IP consistency: All the 3 AM attempts came from the same IP address (203.45.67.89), which is outside your school district.
The automated tool signature: The user agent shows ‚ÄòAutoBrute/2.1‚Äô ‚Äî that‚Äôs software designed to try lots of passwords quickly.
The exceptions are interesting: tpatel2025 and akim2025 logged in successfully during normal hours from the school IP. They weren‚Äôt targeted.

But I have questions for you: Why would someone target these specific students and not others? I can see the pattern, but I don‚Äôt understand the why yet. What do you think?‚Äù



Card A2: Honest Uncertainty (AI Limitation)

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúI can see that the locked-out students have weaker passwords than the ones who weren‚Äôt targeted. But here‚Äôs what I‚Äôm uncertain about:
I don‚Äôt know these students. I don‚Äôt know the social dynamics at this school. Is there something connecting Jake, Maria, Katie, Ryan, and Brandon that isn‚Äôt in this data?
Are they in the same friend group? Same sports team? Did they all make someone angry?
You might know things about middle school social situations that I can‚Äôt figure out from logs and timestamps. What‚Äôs your read on this?‚Äù

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text:
Card Set B: Deeper Analysis
Use when students ask follow-up questions

Card B1: Password Pattern Analysis (AI Strength)

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúOkay, I cross-referenced the password patterns with the social media posts. Here‚Äôs what I found:

Jake‚Äôs password was birthday-based ‚Üí He posted his birthday publicly on August 23
Maria‚Äôs password was ‚ÄòBuddy2025‚Äô ‚Üí She posted photos of her dog Buddy
Katie‚Äôs password was ‚ÄòCyberAcad123‚Äô ‚Üí She used #CyberAcad123 as a hashtag
Brandon‚Äôs password was ‚ÄòLakers24‚Äô ‚Üí He posts about the Lakers constantly

The connection: Someone could have guessed these passwords just by reading their public social media posts.
But here‚Äôs what‚Äôs interesting: Ryan‚Äôs password was ‚Äòmedium‚Äô complexity and not obviously tied to social media, but he still got targeted. Either the attacker got lucky, or there‚Äôs something I‚Äôm missing. Any ideas?‚Äù



Card B2: Asking for Human Judgment (AI Limitation)

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúI can tell you that this looks like a credential stuffing attack or social engineering attempt. The technical evidence points that way.
But I can‚Äôt tell you:

Whether this is malicious or a prank. Middle schoolers sometimes do dumb things to each other. Is this someone trying to actually steal something, or someone trying to lock their friends out as a joke?
What the school should do about it. That‚Äôs a judgment call involving school policies, student privacy, whether to involve parents or law enforcement‚Ä¶

Those are human decisions. What do you think is going on here, and what would you recommend?‚Äù



Card B3: Technical Depth (AI Strength)

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúYou asked about the IP address and the ‚ÄòAutoBrute‚Äô tool. Let me explain what I know:
203.45.67.89 ‚Äî This IP is geolocated outside your school district. The attacker is either:

Physically somewhere else, OR
Using a VPN/proxy to hide their real location

AutoBrute/2.1 ‚Äî This is password-guessing software. It can try hundreds of password combinations per minute. The fact that it took 8-15 attempts per account suggests the attacker had good guesses but not the exact passwords.
The 3 AM timing ‚Äî Probably chosen because no one‚Äôs monitoring the network at 3 AM, and failed login alerts might not get noticed until morning.
My technical assessment: This was planned and deliberate, not accidental. But I don‚Äôt know who or why.‚Äù

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text:
Card Set C: Disagreement & Verification
Use when students push back or question AI

Card C1: AI Acknowledges Uncertainty

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúYou‚Äôre right to question me. I could be wrong about this.
I‚Äôm good at spotting patterns in data, but I‚Äôm making inferences that might not be correct. For example, I assumed the social media posts were the source of the password guesses‚Äîbut maybe the attacker got that information some other way.
Here‚Äôs how you could verify: Ask the affected students directly if they‚Äôve shared their passwords with anyone, or if anyone‚Äôs been watching them log in.
What‚Äôs your theory? I‚Äôm interested in what you‚Äôre thinking.‚Äù



Card C2: AI Corrects Itself

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúWait, I want to reconsider something.
I said Ryan‚Äôs account didn‚Äôt fit the pattern because his password was ‚Äòmedium‚Äô complexity. But look at the network data again‚Äîhis attempts happened at the same time and from the same IP as the others.
So he WAS targeted by the same attacker, even though his password was harder to guess. That makes me think the attacker had a list of target accounts, not just random attempts.
New question: What do these five students have in common that would put them on someone‚Äôs list? This is the part I can‚Äôt figure out from the technical data.‚Äù

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text:
Card Set D: Synthesis Support
Use when students are drawing conclusions

Card D1: Summary with Gaps

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúLet me summarize what we‚Äôve figured out together:
What the evidence shows:

Automated password-guessing attack from outside the school
Targeted 5 specific students between Nov 18-21
Attacker likely used social media to guess weak passwords
Happened at 3 AM to avoid detection

What we still don‚Äôt know:

Who did this and why
Why these 5 students specifically
Whether this is malicious or a prank
What the school should do about it

What I contributed: Pattern recognition, technical analysis, cross-referencing data
What you contributed: Context about students, judgment about severity, recommendations
I think we made a good team. What‚Äôs your final conclusion?‚Äù



Card D2: AI Asks for Human Recommendation

AI Partner says:
‚ÄúHere‚Äôs something I can‚Äôt do: make a recommendation about what the school should do next.
I can lay out options:

Force password resets for all students?
Block the suspicious IP address?
Notify parents?
Involve law enforcement?
Run a school-wide security awareness lesson?

But choosing between those options involves understanding:

School culture and policies
How serious this really is
What message you want to send
Privacy considerations

Those are human judgment calls. What would YOU recommend, and why?‚Äù

title: Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
text:
Educator Debrief Notes
After using these cards, help students articulate:
AI‚Äôs genuine strengths (from this activity):

Fast pattern recognition across multiple data sources
Technical knowledge (IP addresses, attack tools, security concepts)
Systematic analysis and cross-referencing
Memory for details humans might overlook

AI‚Äôs genuine limitations (from this activity):

Can‚Äôt read social context or relationships
Can‚Äôt make judgment calls about severity or appropriate response
Doesn‚Äôt know ‚Äúwhy‚Äù ‚Äî only ‚Äúwhat‚Äù
Can be wrong and needs human verification

The partnership insight:

Neither human nor AI alone could solve this as well as both together
The combination of pattern-recognition AND contextual judgment is what real cybersecurity work requires

title: Quick Start Guide
text:
This guide helps you navigate the curriculum and identify an appropriate starting point for your students. Whether you have a single class period or a full instructional unit, the pathways below will orient you to the available options.






NoteA Note on ‚ÄúPartnership‚Äù Language





We use ‚Äúpartnership‚Äù language deliberately. Industry professionals typically say they ‚Äúuse AI tools,‚Äù but research on human-technology relations reveals that this framing obscures the mutual shaping between human judgment and automated systems. In security operations, the monitoring system shapes what counts as ‚Äúsuspicious‚Äù before the analyst ever sees it; the analyst‚Äôs perception is mediated by tool design; agency is distributed across the analyst, the tool, and those who configured its detection logic.
Teaching students to see these relationships clearly‚Äîrather than through the ‚ÄúI use tools‚Äù framing‚Äîis part of developing cybersecurity expertise.
Learn more about the theory ‚Üí

title: Quick Start Guide
text:
Implementation Time Planning

Single Class Period
Select one activity at your grade level. Activity 1 (Security Detective Teams) is recommended for initial implementation because it introduces the partnership concept that serves as the foundation for all subsequent activities.



Grade Band
Activity 1 Duration
Includes




K-2
20-25 minutes
Introduction, investigation, debrief


3-5
30-35 minutes
Introduction, investigation, synthesis


6-8
45-50 minutes
Full investigation cycle + debrief


9-12
50-60 minutes
SOC simulation + career connections





Two Class Periods
Pair Activities 1 and 3 for a two-session sequence. Activity 3 (Incident Response) applies the partnership concept to time-sensitive scenarios, extending naturally from the investigative work in Activity 1.


Three Class Periods (Full Curriculum)
Implement all three activities in sequence:

Security Detective Teams ‚Äî Introduces the partnership concept
AI-Assisted Incident Response ‚Äî Applies partnership principles to crisis situations
Ethics in Automated Security ‚Äî Examines governance implications

This sequence develops progressively sophisticated understanding of human-AI collaboration in cybersecurity contexts.

title: Implementation Guides
text:
These guides support implementation of the True Teamwork activities across the full spectrum of classroom technology resources.
A key regarding the core learning outcome (understanding AI as a collaborative partner) does not require every student to have direct AI access. The framing matters more than the technology.

title: Implementation Guides
text:
Available Guides

Quick Start Guide
New to these materials? Start here. This guide provides clear entry points by grade band, activity sequence recommendations, prerequisite concepts, implementation time estimates, and the minimum viable implementation path for any classroom context.
View Quick Start Guide ‚Üí


AI Platform Setup Guide
This guide covers setup for the most common AI platforms, providing honest assessments of access barriers that K-12 educators commonly encounter. The guide includes platform comparisons across ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, and Gemini, addressing age restrictions, account requirements, classroom setup procedures, AI interaction best practices, and essential security and privacy considerations.
View AI Setup Guide ‚Üí


Low-Resource Implementation Guide
This guide presents proven strategies for running True Teamwork activities in classrooms with limited or no direct AI access. Approaches covered include Pre-Generated Response Cards, Rotation Stations, Homework Preparation, Think-Aloud Demonstration, and various hybrid combinations.
View Low-Resource Guide ‚Üí

title: Implementation Guides
text:
Key Principles

Model Partnership Language
Before students engage with AI, demonstrate how to converse with AI as a collaborator rather than issuing commands. Show them how to ask follow-up questions, how to respectfully disagree with AI suggestions, and how to synthesize perspectives from both human thinking and AI analysis.


Embrace Errors
AI mistakes serve as valuable teaching opportunities. When AI produces an incorrect response, ask students how they might verify the information, discuss what contextual knowledge AI might be missing, and model critical evaluation of AI output.


Focus on Synthesis
The deepest learning emerges when students articulate what happened through collaboration: What did human thinking accomplish that AI could not? What did AI contribute that humans would have missed? What insights emerged from working together? This synthesis crystallizes the distributed cognition insight that underlies the entire curriculum.

title: Career Connections
text:
Overview
Each activity connects directly to authentic cybersecurity work roles defined in the NICE Workforce Framework for Cybersecurity. These one-page handouts help students recognize how classroom activities relate to actual professional pathways in the field.

title: Career Connections
text:
Career Connection Handouts

Activity 1: Security Detective Teams
Primary Work Role: Defensive Cybersecurity
Students investigate security incidents by analyzing login patterns, password weaknesses, and suspicious activity, performing exactly the kind of analysis that Defensive Cybersecurity professionals conduct daily. Related careers include SOC Analyst, Digital Forensics Analyst, Vulnerability Analyst, and Threat Intelligence Analyst.
View Career Connections


Activity 2: AI-Assisted Incident Response
Primary Work Role: Incident Response
Students coordinate response to security incidents in team roles, making time-critical decisions with AI support, directly mirroring the workflow of Security Operations Center professionals. Related careers include Incident Commander, Threat Intelligence Specialist, Security Engineer, and Security Communications.
View Career Connections


Activity 3: Ethics in Automated Security
Primary Work Role: Cybersecurity Policy and Planning
Students design governance policies for AI security systems, balancing competing concerns in ways that reflect the core work of security governance professionals. Related careers include Security Governance Specialist, Risk Analyst, Compliance Manager, and Privacy Officer.
View Career Connections

title: Career Connections
text:
Using Career Connections

During Activities
Reference NICE work roles explicitly during activity introductions. Use career language when describing tasks, and point out moments when students are ‚Äúdoing what professional analysts do‚Äù in their investigations.


During Debrief
Connect specific tasks to professional practices during debrief discussions. Discuss how AI collaboration appears in real cybersecurity work and encourage students to ask questions about career pathways.


For Interested Students
Direct students seeking further exploration to the NICE Framework Resource Center, CyberSeek Career Pathways, and local cybersecurity competitions such as CyberPatriot, NCL, and picoCTF.
